The illusion is very real, but in most of your beginning examples, I got it correct, not because my brain doesn't have the same biases, but because one version of the "mountain or valley" made more sense in context. Like, the Grand Canyon from above makes a lot more sense geographically if it cuts into the earth rather than the other way around. The Mars picture clearly had craters that made the valleys make more sense in context. And the Snake Creek sign makes far more sense that the letters are cut into the wood, not only because it would be easier to make that way, but also because the texture of the wood reveals the location of the light source anyway, just like the Mars craters do.

The manual shading on the mountains was wrong. That was a shadow cast by the mountain, which is clearly different than a valley's shadow. Instead, the side of the mountain that faces away from the sin should be shaded (i.e. the sun should be high enough for the mountain to not cast a shadow onto the plain, but low enough that it casts one on itself)---that one would be the same as a valley's shading.

All of the images were "valleys." The mars one is obvious valley, the sign has white letters carved into it. I'm rarely ever confused by mountains in satellite imagery because there are very very few mountains that have abrupt edges like canyons or other depressions can have. The few mountains that do have such abrupt edges are typically volcanoes. Flat land practically never has mountainous features rise up out of no where unless there is a volcanic reason for it. Most mountains exist for continent scale tectonic reasons and typically feature no surrounding flat land, or feature gentile gradation from the mountain to the flat areas. Erosion plays a huge factor. Erosion eliminates sharp transitions at the base of mountains. However erosion causes canyons to have abrupt features at the top edges as material becomes unstable and falls away from the original flat plane that once existed before the river or earthquake carved the depression into the landscape.
But hey, that's just how I see things.

The described phenomenon has a practical reason; cartographers used to work with paper maps on desks. Since most people are right handed, desk lamps (and candles, in the older days) are usually positioned on the left side of a table, so that you‘d have the written words illuminated while your hand casts it’s shadow away from the writing. So in order for cartographers to not get confused, the shadows on maps are oriented so that they would line up with any other shadow on the desk!

I have a completely different explanation especially considering that photo of the Grand Canyon because, even when you rotated it, I still saw the same reversal of relief.
Why?
Due to the color/luminosity of the flat surrounding land rather than a persistent assumption of what direction light always comes from. Large areas of one side of the map have lighter colored soil which the brain reflexively interprets as the direction of the light source. Has nothing to do with "must be upper" or "must be upper left". Reverse the luminosity or greyscale of the image only on the flat land outside the mountains/valleys and your brain will flip the direction of assumed light.

Experiment with this and see for yourself.

Well this is false.....not all humans are tricked by this "illusion." You say that a bulge lit from the top leaves a shadow on the bottom and a dent lit from the bottom leaves the same shadow, but that's not actually true in the entirety of the picture.....you have to take into account the pole itself as well. Lighting from the top leaves a shadow on the pole at the bottom of a bulge, but lit from underneath a dent will leave no shadow on neither top or bottom of the pole, the shadow stays within the dent itself.

If the picture is an accurate photo, then a human should be able to tell where the light is coming from and whether it is a mountain or valley given surrounding feature calculation.

The pattern of erosion is another, independent clue, and should take precedence over lighting.  A sharp edge with a flat uniform surface on one side, and trailing streaks of eroding material on the other, is much more likely to be associated with the rim of a plateau than the edge of a valley.  Of course, perceiving this clue doesn't come as naturally as the shadowing clue, since we grow up on the ground and not flying overhead.
